message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and the fact that the patient plays tennis suggest lateral epicondylitis, commonly known as tennis elbow, which is caused by repeated wrist extension. Nerve compression at the elbow and bursal inflammation may also cause elbow pain, but they are less likely in this case. Excessive stress to bone can occur in conditions such as stress fractures, but it is not likely the cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of increased tennis playing suggests that he may have lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow. This is caused by repeated wrist extension movements that strain the extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle insertion at the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. The pain is reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance which puts further strain on this muscle. Nerve compression at the elbow, bursal inflammation, and excessive stress to bone are not typically associated with lateral epicondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, playing tennis recreationally, and the pain being reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance all suggest lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow, which is caused by repeated wrist extension. None of the other options explain these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow, which is caused by repeated wrist extension. Nerve compression would present with different symptoms such as numbness or tingling. Bursal inflammation and excessive stress to bone are less likely causes given the patient's history of recreational tennis and recent increase in frequency of play.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lateral epicondylitis, commonly known as tennis elbow. This condition is caused by excessive stress to the tendons attached to the lateral epicondyle, often due to repeated wrist extension activities like playing tennis. Nerve compression and bursal inflammation can cause elbow pain but are less likely in this case. Excessive stress to bone can cause stress fractures but is not a likely cause of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest lateral epicondylitis, commonly known as "tennis elbow." This condition is usually caused by repeated wrist extension or gripping activities. None of the other options are consistent with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of pain on the outer side of the elbow and pain reproduced by supination suggest lateral epicondylitis, commonly known as tennis elbow. The condition is caused by repeated wrist extension, such as in tennis or other racquet sports. Nerve compression at the elbow would present with different symptoms, while bursal inflammation and excessive stress to bone are less likely causes in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of lateral epicondylitis, commonly known as tennis elbow. The condition is caused by repetitive wrist extension, which causes microtrauma to the tendinous attachments to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. Nerve compression at the elbow would cause different symptoms, while bursal inflammation and excessive stress to bone are less likely causes of the patient's symptoms given his history of playing tennis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain on the outer side of the elbow, especially when reproduced by supination against resistance, is suggestive of lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow. This is typically caused by repeated wrist extension. The other options are less likely to cause this type of pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with lateral epicondylitis, which is commonly known as “tennis elbow” and is caused by repeated wrist extension. Nerve compression at the elbow and bursal inflammation would present with different symptoms, while excessive stress to bone would lead to a stress fracture rather than the tenderness and pain described here.
